004
005package edu.wpi.first.math.controller;
006
007import static edu.wpi.first.units.Units.Volts;
008
009import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.proto.SimpleMotorFeedforwardProto;
010import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.struct.SimpleMotorFeedforwardStruct;
011import edu.wpi.first.units.Measure;
012import edu.wpi.first.units.PerUnit;
013import edu.wpi.first.units.TimeUnit;
014import edu.wpi.first.units.Unit;
015import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.MutVoltage;
016import edu.wpi.first.units.measure.Voltage;
017import edu.wpi.first.util.protobuf.ProtobufSerializable;
018import edu.wpi.first.util.struct.StructSerializable;
019
020/** A helper class that computes feedforward outputs for a simple permanent-magnet DC motor. */
021public class SimpleMotorFeedforward implements ProtobufSerializable, StructSerializable {
022  /** The static gain, in volts. */
023  private final double ks;
024
025  /** The velocity gain, in V/(units/s). */
026  private final double kv;
027
028  /** The acceleration gain, in V/(units/s²). */
029  private final double ka;
030
031  /** The period, in seconds. */
032  private final double m_dt;
033
034  // ** The calculated output voltage measure */
035  private final MutVoltage output = Volts.mutable(0.0);
036
037  /**
038   * Creates a new SimpleMotorFeedforward with the specified gains and period.
039   *
040   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
041   *
042   * @param ks The static gain in volts.
043   * @param kv The velocity gain in V/(units/s).
044   * @param ka The acceleration gain in V/(units/s²).
045   * @param dtSeconds The period in seconds.
046   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
047   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for ka &lt; zero.
048   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for period &le; zero.
049   */
050  public SimpleMotorFeedforward(double ks, double kv, double ka, double dtSeconds) {
051    this.ks = ks;
052    this.kv = kv;
053    this.ka = ka;
054    if (kv < 0.0) {
055      throw new IllegalArgumentException("kv must be a non-negative number, got " + kv + "!");
056    }
057    if (ka < 0.0) {
058      throw new IllegalArgumentException("ka must be a non-negative number, got " + ka + "!");
059    }
060    if (dtSeconds <= 0.0) {
061      throw new IllegalArgumentException(
062          "period must be a positive number, got " + dtSeconds + "!");
063    }
064    m_dt = dtSeconds;
065  }
066
067  /**
068   * Creates a new SimpleMotorFeedforward with the specified gains and period. The period is
069   * defaulted to 20 ms.
070   *
071   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
072   *
073   * @param ks The static gain in volts.
074   * @param kv The velocity gain in V/(units/s).
075   * @param ka The acceleration gain in V/(units/s²).
076   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
077   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for ka &lt; zero.
078   */
079  public SimpleMotorFeedforward(double ks, double kv, double ka) {
080    this(ks, kv, ka, 0.020);
081  }
082
083  /**
084   * Creates a new SimpleMotorFeedforward with the specified gains. Acceleration gain is defaulted
085   * to zero. The period is defaulted to 20 ms.
086   *
087   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
088   *
089   * @param ks The static gain in volts.
090   * @param kv The velocity gain in V/(units/s).
091   * @throws IllegalArgumentException for kv &lt; zero.
092   */
093  public SimpleMotorFeedforward(double ks, double kv) {
094    this(ks, kv, 0);
095  }
096
097  /**
098   * Returns the static gain in volts.
099   *
100   * @return The static gain in volts.
101   */
102  public double getKs() {
103    return ks;
104  }
105
106  /**
107   * Returns the velocity gain in V/(units/s).
108   *
109   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
110   *
111   * @return The velocity gain in V/(units/s).
112   */
113  public double getKv() {
114    return kv;
115  }
116
117  /**
118   * Returns the acceleration gain in V/(units/s²).
119   *
120   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
121   *
122   * @return The acceleration gain in V/(units/s²).
123   */
124  public double getKa() {
125    return ka;
126  }
127
128  /**
129   * Returns the period in seconds.
130   *
131   * @return The period in seconds.
132   */
133  public double getDt() {
134    return m_dt;
135  }
136
137  /**
138   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints assuming continuous control.
139   *
140   * @param velocity The velocity setpoint.
141   * @param acceleration The acceleration setpoint.
142   * @return The computed feedforward.
143   * @deprecated Use the current/next velocity overload instead.
144   */
145  @SuppressWarnings("removal")
146  @Deprecated(forRemoval = true, since = "2025")
147  public double calculate(double velocity, double acceleration) {
148    return ks * Math.signum(velocity) + kv * velocity + ka * acceleration;
149  }
150
151  /**
152   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and velocity setpoint assuming continuous control
153   * (acceleration is assumed to be zero).
154   *
155   * @param velocity The velocity setpoint.
156   * @return The computed feedforward.
157   * @deprecated Use the current/next velocity overload instead.
158   */
159  @SuppressWarnings("removal")
160  @Deprecated(forRemoval = true, since = "2025")
161  public double calculate(double velocity) {
162    return calculate(velocity, 0);
163  }
164
165  /**
166   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints assuming discrete control when the
167   * setpoint does not change.
168   *
169   * @param <U> The velocity parameter either as distance or angle.
170   * @param setpoint The velocity setpoint.
171   * @return The computed feedforward.
172   */
173  public <U extends Unit> Voltage calculate(Measure<? extends PerUnit<U, TimeUnit>> setpoint) {
174    return calculate(setpoint, setpoint);
175  }
176
177  /**
178   * Calculates the feedforward from the gains and setpoints assuming discrete control.
179   *
180   * <p>Note this method is inaccurate when the velocity crosses 0.
181   *
182   * @param <U> The velocity parameter either as distance or angle.
183   * @param currentVelocity The current velocity setpoint.
184   * @param nextVelocity The next velocity setpoint.
185   * @return The computed feedforward.
186   */
187  public <U extends Unit> Voltage calculate(
188      Measure<? extends PerUnit<U, TimeUnit>> currentVelocity,
189      Measure<? extends PerUnit<U, TimeUnit>> nextVelocity) {
190    // See wpimath/algorithms.md#Simple_motor_feedforward for derivation
191    if (ka == 0.0) {
192      output.mut_replace(
193          ks * Math.signum(nextVelocity.magnitude()) + kv * nextVelocity.magnitude(), Volts);
194      return output;
195    } else {
196      double A = -kv / ka;
197      double B = 1.0 / ka;
198      double A_d = Math.exp(A * m_dt);
199      double B_d = 1.0 / A * (A_d - 1.0) * B;
200      output.mut_replace(
201          ks * Math.signum(currentVelocity.magnitude())
202              + 1.0 / B_d * (nextVelocity.magnitude() - A_d * currentVelocity.magnitude()),
203          Volts);
204      return output;
205    }
206  }
207
208  /**
209   * Calculates the maximum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply and an acceleration.
210   * Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal profile are
211   * simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give you a
212   * simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
213   *
214   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
215   *
216   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the motor, in volts.
217   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the motor, in (units/s²).
218   * @return The maximum possible velocity in (units/s) at the given acceleration.
219   */
220  public double maxAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double acceleration) {
221    // Assume max velocity is positive
222    return (maxVoltage - ks - acceleration * ka) / kv;
223  }
224
225  /**
226   * Calculates the minimum achievable velocity given a maximum voltage supply and an acceleration.
227   * Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal profile are
228   * simultaneously achievable - enter the acceleration constraint, and this will give you a
229   * simultaneously-achievable velocity constraint.
230   *
231   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
232   *
233   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the motor, in volts.
234   * @param acceleration The acceleration of the motor, in (units/s²).
235   * @return The maximum possible velocity in (units/s) at the given acceleration.
236   */
237  public double minAchievableVelocity(double maxVoltage, double acceleration) {
238    // Assume min velocity is negative, ks flips sign
239    return (-maxVoltage + ks - acceleration * ka) / kv;
240  }
241
242  /**
243   * Calculates the maximum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply and a velocity.
244   * Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal profile are
245   * simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
246   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
247   *
248   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
249   *
250   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the motor, in volts.
251   * @param velocity The velocity of the motor, in (units/s).
252   * @return The maximum possible acceleration in (units/s²) at the given velocity.
253   */
254  public double maxAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double velocity) {
255    return (maxVoltage - ks * Math.signum(velocity) - velocity * kv) / ka;
256  }
257
258  /**
259   * Calculates the minimum achievable acceleration given a maximum voltage supply and a velocity.
260   * Useful for ensuring that velocity and acceleration constraints for a trapezoidal profile are
261   * simultaneously achievable - enter the velocity constraint, and this will give you a
262   * simultaneously-achievable acceleration constraint.
263   *
264   * <p>The units should be radians for angular systems and meters for linear systems.
265   *
266   * @param maxVoltage The maximum voltage that can be supplied to the motor, in volts.
267   * @param velocity The velocity of the motor, in (units/s).
268   * @return The maximum possible acceleration in (units/s²) at the given velocity.
269   */
270  public double minAchievableAcceleration(double maxVoltage, double velocity) {
271    return maxAchievableAcceleration(-maxVoltage, velocity);
272  }
273
274  /** SimpleMotorFeedforward struct for serialization. */
275  public static final SimpleMotorFeedforwardStruct struct = new SimpleMotorFeedforwardStruct();
276
277  /** SimpleMotorFeedforward protobuf for serialization. */
278  public static final SimpleMotorFeedforwardProto proto = new SimpleMotorFeedforwardProto();
279}
